contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} [[Image:Roland SCD-15 on Diamond MX300.jpg|thumb|A sound card with a MIDI daughterboard attached]] [[Image:Inventec daughterboard LSI 1078.jpg|thumb|A daughterboard for [[Inventec]] server platform that acts as a RAID controller based on LSI 1078 chipset]] A '''daughterboard''', '''daughtercard''', '''mezzanine board''' or '''piggyback board''' is a [[circuit board]] meant to be an extension or "daughter" of a [[motherboard]] (or 'mainboard'), or occasionally of another card. In particular, daughterboards often have [[plugs (connector)|plugs]], [[Jack (connector)|sockets]], [[pins]], [[electrical connector|connectors]], or other attachments for other boards, which is what differentiates them from standard expansion boards such as for [[Peripheral Component Interconnect|PCI]] or [[Industry Standard Architecture|ISA]], which are usually called [[expansion card]]s. In addition, daughterboards usually have only internal [[Electrical connector|connections]] within a [[computer]] or other [[electronics|electronic]] [[machine|device]] rather than any external ones, and usually access the motherboard directly rather than through a [[computer bus]]. Daughterboards are sometimes used in computers in order to allow for expansion cards to fit on their side (or upright), [[parallel (geometry)|parallel]] to the motherboard, usually to maintain a small or slim [[Computer form factor|form factor]]. In this case they can also be called [[riser card]]s, or risers. Daughterboards are also sometimes used to expand the basic functionality of an electronic device, such as when a certain model has features added to it and is released as a new or separate model. Rather than redesign the first model completely, a daughterboard may be added to a special [[Computer port (hardware)|port]] or connector on the motherboard or mainboard. These usually fit on top of and parallel to the board, separated by [[spacer]]s or [[Standoff (separator)|standoff]]s, and are therefore sometimes called '''mezzanine cards''' due to being stacked like the [[mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]] of a [[theatre]]. [[Wavetable]] cards are often [[wikt:mount|mounted]] on [[sound card]]s in this manner. == Types == *[[Enhanced Graphics Adapter]] piggyback board, adds memory beyond 64 KB, up to 256 KB<ref>Market Looks to EGA as De Facto Standard, ''InfoWorld'', Aug 19, 1985</ref> *[[Expanded memory]] piggyback board, adds additional memory to some EMS and EEMS boards<ref>Product Comparison: 16-Bit EMS Memory, ''InfoWorld'', Sep 7, 1987</ref> *ADD daughterboard *RAID daughterboard * [[Network interface controller]] (NIC) daughterboard *CPU Socket daughterboard *Bluetooth daughterboard *Modem daughterboard *AD/DA/DIO daughter-card *Communication daughterboard (CDC) *Server Management daughterboard (SMDC) *Serial ATA connector daughterboard *Robotic daughterboard *Access control List daughterboard *[[Arduino#Shields|Arduino "shield"]] daughterboards. ==See also== *[[Creative Wave Blaster]] *[[M-Module]], an industrial mezzanine standard for modular I/O *[[PowerUP (accelerator)|PowerUP]] accelerators, CPU and memory daughterboard for [[Amiga (computer)|Amiga]] systems *[[Riser card]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Electronics]] [[Category:Motherboard| ]] [[Category:Computer peripherals| ]] {{Compu-hardware-stub}}
